author: @andsegcar
text: Problem with the cursor at 8:33 I THINK it's this: Just like you said, you operate with a cursor. And just like reading from a file, you can't just read twice because the cursor will already be in the End of File. Example: conn = sqlite3.connect('tutorial.db') c = conn.cursor() c.execute('SELECT * FROM stuffToPlot WHERE value = 2') # ^ SET THE CURSOR IN THE START OF THE SELECTED DATA c.fetchall() ^ # RUN THE CURSOR TO THE END OF THE SELECTED DATA AND RETURN EVERYTHING c.fetchall() ^ # CURSOR IS ALREADY AT THE END OF THE SELECTED DATA SO RETURNS NOTHING c.execute('SELECT * FROM stuffToPlot WHERE value = 2') ^ # RE SET THE CURSOR IN THE START OF THE SELECTED DATA  Can someone confirm?

author: @gregf9160
text: There's no 'undo' but SQLITE has standard ROLLBACK  BEGIN; DELETE FROM TABLE WHERE VALUE = 99; ROLLBACK; -- or issue a COMMIT if you're happy you haven't done something wrong  There's a full dynamic journal in the background while the database is doing anything.
